name: Black-winged Stilt
description: It has a thin, straight beak and very long reddish-pink legs, otherwise black-and-white. The head, neck, underparts, rump, and tail are white; the wings, back, and variable head markings (usually more extensive in males) are black. Young birds have a scaly pattern of dark feathers.
spread_note: A vast range – North America from the southern USA to Patagonia, northern and sub-Saharan Africa, patchily in Europe, southern and southeastern Asia, Australia, New Zealand
image_alt: Photo: John Harrison, CC BY-SA 3.0 Wikimedia Commons
proportions: Body length 36–40 cm; tail length 7–8 cm; wing length 21–25 cm; weight 165–205 g
attractions: It forages at the water-land interface. Its leg length allows it to venture into deeper water inaccessible to other waders. In some areas, stilts are resident; northern populations migrate long distances, forming huge flocks of up to thousands during this time. During breeding, they are monogamous, with both parents building the nest and caring for the young.
breeding: Stilts were once exhibited in the Bechyně Waterfowl Pavilion (now Sichuan) in the 1970s, but detailed records are missing. The birds in the European aviary at Bird Wetlands have been kept since 2010.
